meanings.definition: To lose blood from the body
meanings.sent1: When I cut my finger, it started to bleed.
meanings.sent2: The injured soldier began to bleed heavily.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally made the tomato bleed while cutting it.
meanings.sent4: Her heart seemed to bleed with every painful memory.
meanings.sent5: The red liquid seemed to bleed out of the wound.

meanings.definition: To remove air or liquid from a container
meanings.sent1: I had to bleed the air out of the brake lines.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic needed to bleed the radiator to remove the air bubbles.
meanings.sent3: The balloon started to bleed air slowly after being pricked.
meanings.sent4: The sound of air bleeding out of the tire was loud.
meanings.sent5: She used a pump to bleed the excess water from the fish tank.

meanings.definition: To show through a material, such as ink on paper
meanings.sent1: The marker bled through the thin paper.
meanings.sent2: The ink started to bleed on the wet paper.
meanings.sent3: The colors began to bleed together on the canvas.
meanings.sent4: The wet paintbrush caused the colors to bleed into each other.
meanings.sent5: The dye from the fabric bled onto the white shirt.

meanings.definition: To feel intense emotions, such as fear or sadness
meanings.sent1: She could feel her heart bleed with sorrow.
meanings.sent2: After the breakup, he would often bleed with sadness.
meanings.sent3: The movie made her heart bleed with empathy for the characters.
meanings.sent4: His words made her heart bleed with regret.
meanings.sent5: The tragic news made the whole community bleed with grief.
